text:
The Prince Albert Times and Saskatchewan Review, published by J. D. Maveety.

Notice

The Annual Meeting of the Large Assembly will be held in the Council Chamber on Thursday, November 16th.

For the purpose of hearing the Annual Report, the Election of Officers for 1889 and any other business connected or relating to the interests of the society.

John H. Howard,
Sec., Treas., L.A.S.

Legislative Assembly

The speech of His Honor the Lieutenant-Governor at the opening of the first session of the Territorial Legislature has come to hand, and we are pleased to notice that he touched upon nearly all matters requiring the attention of the law-makers. In fact it cannot be said that His Honor has neglected to bring to the notice of the Assembly anything of public interest. The speech contains, among other things, a reference to the revision and codification of the Ordinances of the North West Council which has been made by His Lordship Judge Richardson and Mr. Justice Macdonald, and names as revised will be submitted to the Assembly for their approval, and will as a matter of course be passed. A revision of the Ordinances has long been felt to be a necessity, and if it is not done now, it does nothing more than they will have accomplished a good work. Attention is also called to the question of prairie fires, and His Honor very properly points out that the existing laws in reference thereto are defective and unsatisfactory and that new legislation is necessary; in this we entirely agree with His Honor and we trust that the law will be very wisely framed. One of the features of the Speech is the reference made to the necessity for an act respecting vital statistics; such an act has long been felt to be a public necessity, and we are sure that any legislation in this direction would meet with most cordial approval. His Honor makes a lengthened reference to the success of the agricultural operations throughout the Territories during the past summer, and speaks most encouragingly of the capacity of the soil of the country. The liquor question is also referred to, and the Assembly invited to consider the matter. As there is no subject at the present time more important than this, we express the hope that the deliberations of the Assembly will tend to a solution of the difficulties which have hitherto existed in regard to the matter. The Assembly cannot legislate on the liquor question, but it can make recommendations to the Imperial Parliament which would most likely be accepted and acted upon by them. It therefore behoves our legislators to act in the most careful manner until this question comes before them, and we trust that whatever is done will be to the advantage of our country and the cause of temperance. We congratulate His Honor on the able and satisfactory manner in which he has managed the affairs of the North-West. It is evident that he has a complete knowledge of the country and its requirements, and evinces a desire to do only what must be for the public welfare. He has been only a few months in office, but so far his administration has been eminently satisfactory to all classes and parties, and he has shown his intention of making reforms where they were required.

Removal

R. C. Wigmore & Co. have removed to their new premises, second door east of old stand. Where they will be pleased to meet their numerous new and old customers. Clearing Sale still going on.

NORTHWEST ASSEMBLY.

EDMONTON, Alta., Nov. 1.—There was a large attendance in the Assembly Hall at the opening of the first session of the Northwest Assembly yesterday—numbering over two hundred members of various occupations who had gathered here for the purpose of discussing matters of public importance.

The Lieutenant-Governor Royal addressed the Assembly in his opening address, congratulating them on their election and thanking them for their support. He also expressed his hope that they would continue to work together to improve the province.

The Assembly adjourned at 12 noon and reconvened at 3 pm.

ELECTION OF OFFICERS.

The Assembly elected the following officers:

- Speaker: Mr. Thomas Wilson
- Deputy Speaker: Mr. William Taylor
- Secretary: Mr. James Smith

The Assembly also approved the following motions:

- Motion: "That the Assembly be adjourned until further notice."
- Motion: "That the Assembly be dissolved."

The Assembly adjourned at 5 pm.

AGENTS:

P.G. GRAY, Edmonton, Alta.

J. FRASER TIMS, Fort Saskatchewan Alt.

Mahaffey & Clinkskill, Battleford, Sask.
TERRITORIAL NEWS

BATTLEFORD.

From the Herald, Oct. 27.

There was still fighting worth nothing.

The battle purchased in Prince Albert by Mr. Macdonald, has been fought for several weeks, but that town was not attacked until the 15th, but have been delayed by the deep snow. They are now engaged in shortly.

The telegraph service has been removed from Battleford to Regina. Mr. Gibson, district superintendent, is on the road now, and will be back here within a few days.

Sgt. Wilson of the mounted police, has been sent out to find the missing man. The sergeant has gone to Battleford to try the efficacy of the springs on a somewhat obstinate individual.

CALGARY.

From the Tribune, Oct. 31.

We have heard that yesterday the Indians came to see us off after the work was done. We had to leave the car with Mr. Macdonald's stone on board; he was on the train and they can't get away with him. We are going to stay here until we can get back to the station house. The Indians claimed to find some of the horses but the Indians said they could not go up without proof and from this the affair seemed to end. According to sworn evidence in the colony's name only one man is known to have been killed—Mr. Hector.

EDMONTON.

From the Bulletin, Oct. 27.

A large block of wood was seen last week in Belcourt settlement.

A large block of wood was seen last week in Belcourt settlement.

Expected that on Sunday morning last, a number of police on the lookout for tramps would have been sent out to change several tents with him to secure his safety, without, however, any damage or loss. It is also said that the Blackfoot Indians are friendly with Government and by some is thought to still be with him, in District, who stood off the police last year at Blackfoot.

DUNLIFFE.

Miss Monger was married on Wednesday last to Mr. N. Nelson, of your town.

Owing to the river being impassable, the meeting on last Sunday was abandoned, and the settlers have decided to write to Mr. Mitchell, referentially to our representative at Regina.

Mr. N. Mitchell purposes celebrating his birthday on Saturday by a grand dinner.

Mr. Lovell, having finished threshing on Beaver's reply, will move the machine to Smith's nearby early next week.

The south branch of the Saskatchewan flows over on Thursday morning, and light snows covered in the afternoon at Battleford.

Indians say any for will be very plentiful this year. From fifteen to twenty skins come to this place.

Some of the men in this district who lately returned from Battleford and across the line are very hard up, and in need of food. Shining, shopping has been good.

One of our most trusted settlers will shortly be among us.

On Tuesday evening Mr. Macdonald tried to cross the river at Battleford with a team of oxen, and soon on the middle of the stream the ice gave way. After two hours' hard work, they were got off.

Our mail has been commenced heading yet.

Weather clear and cool, with little rain.

A TERRIBLE ILLNESS.

Chas. H. Smith, Edmonton, Oct., writes:

My wife suffered for five years with that distressing disease, catarrh. Her case was very serious, and she thought she was near death. She tried all the various remedies advised, but they were of no use. I finally gave up all hope. But Mrs. Smith, who was a great believer in the fluid, took it and was cured. She now feels like a new person. I feel it my duty to say that this fluid is a great blessing to me and I commend it for remedial purposes and am pleased to have all such sufferers know that there is a remedy which will relieve them.

NOTICE.

The Secretary of the Local Agricultural Society has been authorized to offer land not less than five acres, situated in the Municipality of Prince Albert, for sale at $2 per acre. This offer is accepted.

The communications relating to the above notice should be sent at an early date to the Sec-Treasurer, so that the sale may be held at the earliest possible date.

JOHN H. HOWARD,
Sec-Treasurer L. A. S.
